reporting-org.narrative: IRC International Water and Sanitation Centre

description.narrative:
1. Creation of a global hub to support the Agenda for Change, SWA and other partnerships: - A strong partnership of NGOs and philanthropists committed to the Agenda for Change - Successful advocacy for national systems building, increased finance and appropriate financial models for the sector - Successful advocacy for service delivery; government leadership; use of national systems; public finance; research and learning in the global WASH arena - Effective global sharing of news, evidence, experience, tools and approaches
Key results by 2021: Agenda for Change recognised as a catalytic movement achieving visible results; increased sector support for, and understanding of, national and local systems building; increased sector support for public finance as a critical element of WASH financing
2. Creation of national hubs supporting the Agenda for Change partnerships in all our six current and up to four new countries: - Creation of hubs and partnerships - Development and implementation of strategies for national systems strengthening - Effective advocacy for increased government leadership and public finance - Effective advocacy for increased focus on gender mainstreaming and ensuring access for marginalised socio-economic groups - Effective support of knowledge management (e.g., documentation, sharing, learning platforms)
Key results by 2021: Strong government-led partnerships with clear visions, strategies and plans for achieving universal access by 2030; Ngor and other commitments for public finance to the WASH sector are being respected; significant progress on national level building blocks (priority finance and monitoring), increased equity of access for women and marginalised groups
Building WASH systems for the Sustainable Development Goals - Ghana

Our vision is of a world where WASH services are fundamental utilities that everyone is able to take for granted, for good. Our mission is to act as a think-and-do-tank working with local and national governments, non-governmental organisations and with people in communities to help them to build the systems that will achieve this vision. We have a new 14-year Strategic Framework covering the period 2017-30, which is focused on our contribution to the Sustainable Development Goals. This includes a medium-term plan for the next five years (2017-21) which contains key results and activities. The Theory of Change underpinning our strategy sets out our core role as a change hub – at global, national and district levels – supporting broad networks of partners to build the national and local systems necessary for universal and sustainable access to water, sanitation and hygiene by 2030. In order to achieve this goal there has to be a focused and deliberate effort to strengthen local and national systems. In particular, it requires strong local and national government systems for planning, financing and monitoring water and sanitation service delivery. It also calls for improved systems of aid effectiveness between development partners and governments. Working in partnership (through collective action) to build strong national systems is at the heart of our strategy. Because we are members of an important set of networks and alliances, we are well positioned to play the role of a global change hub in pursuit of SDG 6.

comment.narrative: 02-07-2021: This includes both in person and virtual trainings.
14-10-2020: All training programmes planned fro 2018 were carried out with full participation from partners.

14-10-2020: Target was training 500 people, but 1290 people were trained or participated in IRC events over the period. Out of the number 734 were at the national level training and events and 556 were at the District training and events

description.narrative: No. working groups-platforms/target no. working groups-platforms

comment.narrative: 02-07-2021: Two are at Asutifi district level and 6 at national level
14-10-2020: 5 working groups or platforms supported, target equals actual
14-10-2020: IRC Ghana supported 9 working groups of platforms over the period with 1173 people participating. the NLLAP accounted for over 45% of the people participating in the events.

14-10-2020: In 2018 IRC Ghana actively participated and shared project lessons (District based Initiative , Watershed, SC4G etc)and other experiences on the national and international platforms. The platforms at the National level include - NLLAP, SWN Beyond the Pipe Forum, National Sanitation Stocktaking Forum, Mole Conference; and at the International level Watetrshed Annual Meeting in Uganda, Africa Water Week in Gabon and UNC Water and Health Conference, Chapel Hill, USA

title.narrative: National partnership is driving actions of government, private sector, civil society and communities that share the vision for SDG6

comment.narrative: 02-07-2021: The rural water subsector has been under transition to become a rural utility. The sanitation subsector has been working to set up a sanitation authority, however, this has been delayed. The role of private sector in the sanitation subsector continues to increase. As hygiene is cross cutting. With the outbreak of COVID 19 pandemic, the MSWR and MoH have been working closely to promote the hygiene guidelines and protocols. The pandemic however exposed the need for further clarity in the roles and collaboration required.
14-10-2020: MSWR has engaged key sector stakeholders in a series consultations to forge partnerships for delivery of WASH services.

14-10-2020: The MSWR has developed a MTDP and has identified partners within the SDG baseline report. The sector working group was revamped in 2019 and development partners have been meeting with the ministry to coordinate and implement programmes in the sector. However, with the transition in the rural water subsector ( changing to utlity), there is not much clarity on partners roles and responisibilities going forward.

title.narrative: Highest national executive levels are political & financial committed to implement the national strategic plans aligned with SDG6 targets

comment.narrative: 02-07-2021: The highest national executive continue to be commited to national targets and tge SDGs. Many of the national targets and indicators are aligned with the SDGs and other targets. The ministry continues to revise its National Water policy to respond to the SDG targets.With the outbreak of the COVID 19 WASH issues became more pronounced and the national executives increased financing for WASH. The water bills for the citizens was waived by Government from April-December 2020. It is still unclear if the investment is adequate to meet the set targets.

14-10-2020: National leadership has provided leadership and guidance to implementing the SDGs in all sectors in Ghana including WASH - http://www.gh.undp. org/content/ghana/en/home/library/poverty/ghana-sdgs-indicator-baseline-report-2018-.html

14-10-2020: The President and the WASH sector minister have all committed to the SGDs. The NDPC has collated and published baseline information published in 2018. The WASH sector establised golden indicators aligned to the SDGs. The key indicators have been agreed on and included in the Ministry`s Medium Term Development Plan and the national SDG baseline report.
